III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty
to perform the prescribed functions required by these
administrative rules and in the agency's program statement
and to provide for the continual needs, protection, and
supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A has stated that he does not feel safe at the facility. It has
been stated that the youth cannot be moved pods because of
administrative reasons. Youth’s safety concerns are not being
addressed. Other youth block Youth A’s doorway preventing him
from getting out of his room.
Investigation The Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 09/04/2024
and had no other information to provide.
Administrator was interviewed on 07/23/2024 during an
unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He confirmed Youth
A had been moved from one pod to another on several occasions
since his placement at the facility, and these decisions were made
with his safety and the safety of other youth in mind.
Youth A was interviewed on 07/23/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. He stated he felt safe at the
facility. At the time of the interview, he was placed in a pod with
other youth who had been placed at the facility for longer times,
and Youth A believed this was the safest pod in the program
because of that. Youth A remarked in previous pods he felt he
had been antagonized by other youth and confirmed he had been
in fights with other youth. Youth A stated there were no times that
he could recall where staff were not present or did not act quickly
enough to attempt to de-escalate and stop fights between he and
other youth. Youth A stated there was one instance in particular
where he did not feel safe, and this occurred because another
youth attempted to block his doorway when Youth A was in his
own room and attempting to leave. He confirmed he was not
secluded in his room because he was in it alone and his door was
2

open. Youth A stated that Youth B came up to his doorway and
attempted to shut him inside of his room. Youth A recalled staff
coming to get in between Youth B and the door, allowing Youth A
to leave his room. Youth A stated he never heard a staff member
remark anything negative about this incident, or about himself.
Youth B was interviewed on 07/23/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth B recalled the incident
described by Youth A. Youth B stated Youth A had been
antagonizing him and in response, Youth B attempted to close
Youth A in his own room. Youth B recalled staff jumped in front of
him and he was not able to do so. Youth B described the incident
as quick, and that staff intervened to stop it. Youth B believed it
ended when he decided to walk away from Youth A to his own
room at that point.
Youth A’s DHHS Foster Care Worker was interviewed over email
on 07/24/2024. She confirmed she spoke with Youth A in
response to these allegations and Youth A reported to her they
were untrue. She stated she did not have any concerns about
Youth A’s placement at the facility.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone on 07/29/2024. He stated
he was familiar with the incident described by Youth A between
Youth A and Youth B. Staff 1 recalled similar details to both of the
youth interviewed, in that Youth B did attempt to block Youth A’s
doorway but was unsuccessful because of proper staff
intervention. He stated there were many occasions in his work
with Youth A where conflict arose between Youth A and other
youth, but none that resulted in anything more than brief “tussling”
that was stopped by quick staff intervention.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 09/04/2024 over the phone. She
stated she was familiar with Youth A and felt that he was unsafe
because he had regularly been beaten up by other youth and had
to frequently move pods as a result. Staff 2 recalled intervening
herself in these fights on occasion, and did not express any
concern over how those incidents were handled by other staff.
Staff 2 also remarked that supervision at the facility did not want to
move Youth A but “had to” as a result of safety issues. She could
not provide any other information on how that was known.
Documentation reviewed:
• Documentation of Youth A’s placements within certain pods
during his placement at the facility was provided. He was
initially placed on 05/14/2024 in pod 2. On 06/12/2024 he
3

was moved to pod 5. As of July 2024, he was still placed
on pod 5 but other youth had been moved to other pods
due to conflict with Youth A.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed. There was no evidence
found that the facility has not provided adequate protection and
supervision of Youth A.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
